data.title: LXP Industrial Trust raises dividend by 3.7% to $0.14
data.description:
• LXP Industrial Trust (LXP) declares $0.14/share quarterly dividend, 3.7% increase from prior dividend of $0.14.
  • Forward yield 5.95%
  • Payable Jan. 15; for shareholders of record Dec. 30; ex-div Dec. 30.
  • See LXP Dividend Scorecard, Yield Chart, & Dividend Growth.

data.title: Core Scientific fails to get enough votes for CoreWeave deal
data.description:
Core Scientific (CORZ) said it didn't receive the requisite number of votes to approve the company's planned sale to CoreWeave (CRWV) at a special meeting on Thursday. Core Scientific fell 2.4%.

Final voting results will be reported in an 8-K filing, according to a  statement on Thursday.

The announcement is expected after proxy advisory firms including ISS and Glass Lewis came out against the deal as well as some of CoreWeave's largest shareholders. Core Scientific holders had publicly come out against the proposed $9 billion deal, saying that it undervalued CORZ. 

CoreWeave and Core Scientific entered into a definitive agreement on July 7, 2025, under which CoreWeave will acquire Core Scientific in an all-stock transaction. Upon closing, and under the terms of the agreement, Core Scientific stockholders will receive 0.1235 newly issued shares of CoreWeave Class A common stock for each share of Core Scientific common stock held.

data.title: Guardant Health jumps after beating Q3 estimates and increasing FY outlook
data.description:
Guardant Health (GH) shares jumped nearly 30% on Thursday during early trading hours after the company beat third quarter earnings as well as revenue estimates and raised its full-year 2025 revenue outlook.

The California-based company increased its full year 2025 revenue outlook to a range of $965 million to $970 million, representing approximately 31% growth compared to 2024.

For the third quarter, the company reported non-GAAP EPS of $0.39, beating consensus by $0.10, while revenue of $265.2 million was $29.51 million higher than consensus.

Michael Bell, chief financial officer, stated, "Total revenue for the third quarter grew 39% to $265.2 million driven by strong performance across all 3 major revenue lines: oncology, biopharma and data, and screening."

The company also increased its Shield revenue guidance to $71 million to $73 million, up from $55 million to $60 million, with expected volume of 80,000 to 82,000 tests, compared to prior guidance of 68,000 to 73,000 tests.

Guardant Health said it plans for 2025 non-GAAP operating expenses in the range of $865 million to $875 million and continues to expect company-wide cash flow breakeven by the end of 2027.

data.description:

data.title: Gannett strikes AI pact with Microsoft ahead of publisher marketplace launch
data.description:
Gannett (GCI) said on Thursday it has struck an AI licensing pact with Microsoft (MSFT). The partnership comes ahead of the software and cloud giant's launch of Publisher Content Marketplace.

The financial terms of the deal between the two were not disclosed.

In September, Axios reported that Microsoft is in talks with select U.S. publishers about a pilot program to help launch a two-sided marketplace that would compensate publishers for their content used by AI products.

The Axios report had mentioned that Microsoft's Copilot assistant will serve as the first AI buyer within the marketplace for publishers to sell their content. The tech giant is also looking to grow the marketplace's demand-side offering to include other AI products.

data.title: Eagle Materials targets $475M-$500M in FY26 capital spending with major plant upgrades while launching cement price increases
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Eagle Materials Inc. (EXP) Q2 2026

Management View

  • Michael Haack, CEO, opened by highlighting record revenue of $639 million, a gross margin of 31.3%, and earnings per share (EPS) of $4.23 for the quarter. He credited the results to the team’s operational performance despite “headwinds from the residential construction pullback.”
  • Haack detailed strategic progress, including “significant progress on our Laramie, Wyoming plant modernization and expansion and commenced construction of our Duke, Oklahoma Wallboard plant upgrade.” He stated both projects are on budget and on schedule, directly aligned with the company's capital allocation principles.
  • Haack noted the company’s strong safety record, stating, “Eagle Materials has a fantastic safety track record, consistently performing below the industry average for total recordable incident rates across all of our businesses.”
  • On business outlook, Haack said, “We have announced price increases across most of our markets effective January 1, 2026.” He also observed that “Wallboard volumes this quarter are affected by reduced demand due to high interest rates and affordability challenges,” but emphasized the stability in wallboard pricing.
  • Haack described major ongoing investments: “At our Laramie, Wyoming cement plant, we are on track to complete our $430 million modernization and expansion project by the end of calendar 2026,” which will lower manufacturing costs by 25%. The Duke, Oklahoma Wallboard plant modernization is expected to reduce unit production costs by about 20%.
  • CFO D. Kesler reported, “Second quarter revenue was a record $639 million, up 2% from the prior year. The increase was driven by higher cement sales volume and the contribution from the recently acquired aggregates businesses.” He added, “Second quarter earnings per share was $4.23, down 1% from the second quarter of fiscal 2025.”

Outlook

  • The company maintains a reserved near-term view on residential construction due to ongoing high interest rates, impacting wallboard demand. Haack reiterated, “We do not obsess over near-term demand drivers. We run our businesses and invest in their long-term growth.”
  • Announced cement price increases will take effect January 1, 2026, in most markets.
  • Kesler stated, “Considering these 2 projects as well as our sustaining capital spending, we expect total company capital spending in fiscal '26 to be in the range of $475 million to $500 million.”
  • On future capital plans, Kesler noted that spending is likely to step down to “$400 million to $425 million in that range for fiscal '27” with a further decrease in fiscal '28.

Financial Results

  • Record revenue for Q2 2026 reached $639 million, with gross margin at 31.3% and EPS of $4.23, as reported by both Haack and Kesler.
  • In the Heavy Materials sector, revenue increased by 11%, with concrete and aggregates revenue up 24%, and record aggregate sales volume rising 103% (including acquisitions). Organic aggregate sales volume rose 35%.
  • Light Materials sector revenue decreased by 13% to $213 million, reflecting lower wallboard sales volume and a 2% decrease in wallboard sales prices. Operating earnings in this sector were down 20% to $78 million.
  • Operating cash flow for the quarter was $205 million, down 12% due to working capital and tax timing. Capital spending increased to $109 million, mainly for the Mountain Cement and Duke Wallboard projects.
  • $97 million was returned to shareholders in the quarter through share repurchases and dividends.
  • Net debt-to-cap ratio at September 30, 2025, was 45%, with net debt-to-EBITDA leverage at 1.6x and $35 million in cash on hand.

Q&A

  • Trey Grooms, Stephens: Asked about the 14% decline in wallboard volume and drivers for quarter-to-quarter swings. Kesler responded, “We saw the production from the builders pullback during the July, August time frame… quarter-to-quarter shifts happen that can be more noise than anything.”
  • Grooms: Inquired about wallboard pricing stability. Kesler said, “We’re more oriented to price than we are volume... we've taken the approach of value over volume.”
  • Grooms: On cement volume outlook, Kesler explained, “Infrastructure spending and private nonres... have continued to be strong demand drivers. We saw that here in the last quarter... volumes have continued to trend positive.”
  • Andrew Maser, Stifel: Asked about organic aggregates growth. Haack highlighted, “35% growth on our existing operations was also in there from some of the capital improvements we made.”
  • Maser: On margin outlook for aggregates, Kesler said, “This is a much more normal run rate... very happy with how that business has performed coming into this year.”
  • Brent Thielman, D.A. Davidson: Asked about cement pricing and oil well impact. Kesler clarified, “Oil well cement has become a much smaller percentage of our business... pricing within the wholly owned business... is actually pretty stable.”
  • Anthony Pettinari, Citigroup: Asked about CapEx and cash tax impact from new projects. Kesler stated, “Capital spending for fiscal '26... still expect to be $475 million to $500 million... the Mountain Cement plant goes in service in fiscal '27, which would significantly reduce cash taxes paid in fiscal '27.”
  • Unknown Analyst: Queried on underlying cement demand. Kesler said, “Cement demand typically grows in the 2% to 4% range... jobs don’t get eliminated, they just get delayed.”
  • Jonathan Bettenhausen, Truist: Asked if price increases applied to wallboard. Kesler replied, “Just in cement.”

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed on declining wallboard volumes, pricing resilience, cement demand sustainability, and margin trends, reflecting a slightly negative to neutral sentiment regarding near-term demand, but acknowledged the company’s operational strengths.
  • Management maintained a confident and long-term oriented tone in prepared remarks, but was more reserved and cautious when addressing short-term demand and volume questions during Q&A. Haack and Kesler both used language emphasizing discipline and optimism for long-term growth.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, the tone shifted slightly toward caution on residential construction, while maintaining strong confidence in heavy materials and strategic investments.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Q2 saw a decrease in EPS and light materials revenue compared to Q1, with a sharper focus on headwinds in residential construction. Wallboard volume and sales prices declined more noticeably, while cement and aggregates growth accelerated with strong volume and revenue increases.
  • Guidance language shifted to emphasize capital allocation for modernization and expansion, with detailed timelines and spending projections for fiscal '26 through '28.
  • Analysts moved from requesting broad outlooks to probing specific drivers behind segment swings and cost/control outlooks.
  • Management’s confidence in long-term strategy and capital discipline remained consistent, but with added caution regarding short-term demand fluctuations, especially in the wallboard segment.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management identified high interest rates and housing affordability as primary risks impacting wallboard demand.
  • Analysts raised concerns about the volatility in wallboard volumes, pricing stability, and competitive pressures in cement, with management reiterating their focus on value over volume and price leadership.
  • No significant new risks were raised regarding the company’s financial structure or ability to fund capital projects.

Final Takeaway

Eagle Materials delivered record second quarter revenue and gross margin amid mixed demand conditions, led by strength in cement and aggregates and offset by weakness in wallboard. Management emphasized disciplined capital allocation, price increases for cement, and major modernization projects, while remaining cautious about near-term residential construction headwinds. The company reiterated its commitment to long-term growth, shareholder returns, and operational excellence as it navigates market challenges and invests in high-return projects.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Sirius XM raises 2025 guidance by $25M with focus on free cash flow and spectrum value
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Sirius XM Holdings Inc. (SIRI) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Jennifer Witz stated the company is "increasing our full year 2025 guidance by $25 million across revenue, EBITDA and free cash flow" and is confident that ongoing business improvements will drive growth in free cash flow toward the target of $1.5 billion by 2027. Witz also revealed that Sirius XM is "actively exploring ways to unlock the long-term strategic value of our spectrum assets."
  • The CEO highlighted "solid momentum in our new SiriusXM acquisition initiatives with ongoing expansion of our 3-year automotive dealer subscription program and our Podcasts+ offering as well as continued strength in retention." She also noted a "pullback on streaming marketing spend" as the main reason for a decline in self-pay net adds, while retention remained strong.
  • Witz described advancements in programming, including exclusive events and partnerships such as "the return of Channel 13 to celebrate Taylor Swift's new album," the launch of Maximum Metallica, and expanded deals with Andy Cohen, Stephen A. Smith, and Megyn Kelly.
  • The CEO reported a "more than a 50% increase in NFL and MLB play-by-play listeners, and almost tripled the usage of our artist-seated stations."
  • Witz discussed the rollout of a new identity framework shifting subscriptions from vehicle-based to customer-based models, aiming to "drive stronger customer acquisition, higher retention and sustained revenue growth."
  • EVP & Chief Financial Officer Thomas Barry stated, "Total revenue for the third quarter was $2.16 billion, essentially flat year-over-year, down less than 1%. Subscriber revenue declined by $16 million to $1.63 billion, while advertising revenue grew by $5 million to $455 million." Barry added, "free cash flow was $257 million, up from $93 million in the third quarter of 2024."

Outlook

  • The company raised guidance by $25 million each for total revenue, adjusted EBITDA, and free cash flow to approximately $8.525 billion in revenue, $2.625 billion in adjusted EBITDA, and $1.225 billion in free cash flow for 2025. Barry commented, "we remain confident in our ability to close this year strong."
  • Witz highlighted continued progress toward a free cash flow target of $1.5 billion by 2027 and noted, "As we continue to drive profitability, achieve our target leverage ratio and move towards our free cash flow target of $1.5 billion in 2027, we expect to have expanded opportunities for capital returns."

Financial Results

  • Barry reported, "Adjusted EBITDA was $676 million, down 2% year-over-year with a 31% margin." Net income reached $297 million, and free cash flow increased to $257 million.
  • SiriusXM total revenue ended the quarter at $1.61 billion, with advertising revenue steady at $39 million. Average revenue per user rose to $15.19. Segment gross profit was $958 million, with a 59% margin.
  • Self-pay net adds were negative 40,000. Churn remained healthy at 1.6%.
  • Pandora and Off-platform revenue was $548 million, with subscriber revenue declining to $132 million and advertising revenue growing to $416 million. Podcast revenue increased nearly 50% year-over-year. Segment gross profit was $170 million, with a 31% margin.
  • Sales and marketing expenses fell 15% to $176 million. Product and technology costs were down 5% to $54 million. G&A expenses increased 2% to $115 million. Subscriber acquisition costs rose to $107 million.
  • The revolving credit facility was increased and extended to $2 billion, with only $30 million drawn. Net debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio was 3.8x. The company reduced total debt by $120 million and returned $111 million to shareholders.

Q&A

  • Stephen Laszczyk, Goldman Sachs: Asked about net adds and underlying business momentum. Witz responded that the decline in net adds was expected due to reduced streaming marketing but expects improved in-car business and contributions from acquisition initiatives. She noted, "we really believe we're going to see continued progress ... as a result of the expanded pricing and packaging we put in place, better personalized and content-led marketing, leveraging 360L, other third-party data."
  • Laszczyk followed up on ARPU trends and pricing changes. Witz said, "we're on track on ARPU in terms of better year-over-year comparisons" and expects "opportunity to continue to improve ARPU over time."
  • Cameron Mansson-Perrone, Morgan Stanley: Inquired about pricing frequency and peer influence. Witz indicated openness to more frequent rate increases: "there's a possibility that we'll do it maybe more frequently or ... 18 months."
  • Mansson-Perrone asked about podcasting's share of ad business. Witz noted podcasting ad revenue was "up about 50%" and expects continued growth, while also aiming to improve streaming and satellite ad performance.
  • Kutgun Maral, Evercore ISI: Sought details on spectrum monetization. EVP & COO Wayne Thorsen explained, "our spectrum holdings total about 35 megahertz ... we are evaluating multiple approaches to creating value right now." Witz emphasized focus on organic investment, delevering, and potential for future capital returns.
  • Barton Crockett, Rosenblatt Securities: Asked about spectrum sale and auto relationships. Witz said selling spectrum is not the main focus and emphasized leveraging partnerships. Thorsen highlighted SiriusXM's strong relationships with OEMs and robust positioning in both CarPlay and native interfaces.
  • Matthew Harrigan, Benchmark Company: Asked about video monetization opportunities. President Scott Greenstein detailed growth on YouTube and flexibility in video distribution, stating, "we're in a good position to see what's out there, field some offers and decide what's best for the company."
  • Omar Mejias Santiago, Wells Fargo: Questioned cost reductions. Barry said, "we've optimized more of the marketing side this year," and noted ongoing structural and project-based cost initiatives. Witz added, "ultimately, we're focused on increasing free cash flow and driving future value creation for our shareholders."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed for clarity on net add trends, pricing frequency, spectrum monetization, and cost efficiencies, reflecting a neutral to slightly positive tone as they sought confirmation on strategic execution and growth levers.
  • Management maintained a confident and measured tone, repeatedly referencing disciplined execution, ongoing progress, and opportunities for further growth. Witz stated, "we feel good about the trends" and Barry remarked on "continued strength of our operations and our disciplined execution."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analysts appeared more focused on strategic initiatives and monetization opportunities, while management displayed increased confidence, especially around guidance and capital returns.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The company increased guidance for revenue, EBITDA, and free cash flow by $25 million, compared to reaffirmation in the previous quarter.
  • Management reiterated progress on cost savings and highlighted a significant improvement in free cash flow, up from $93 million in Q3 2024 and $402 million in Q2 2025.
  • Strategic focus shifted to unlocking spectrum value and enhancing pricing/packaging, as well as podcasting and advertising growth, compared to prior emphasis on cost discipline and in-car experience.
  • Analysts' questions shifted from cost structure and ad-supported plans last quarter to spectrum monetization and more granular pricing strategy this quarter.
  • Management tone showed increased confidence, particularly regarding free cash flow and capital returns, compared to the more cautious approach seen previously.

Risks and Concerns

  • Witz cited "pullback on streaming marketing spend" as the main driver of the decline in self-pay net adds, and noted some "headwinds in the fourth quarter from reduced streaming marketing and acquisition channels."
  • Management is "watching closely" for impacts from auto sales, specifically mentioning "the ever-evolving tariff situation and potential impacts if that were to affect consumer demand."
  • The company remains "committed to prudent investments and maintaining our dividend policy," while monitoring leverage and capital return flexibility.

Final Takeaway

Sirius XM’s third quarter was marked by a $25 million upward revision in full-year guidance for revenue, EBITDA, and free cash flow, with management confident in reaching a $1.5 billion free cash flow target by 2027. The company is actively exploring strategic options for its spectrum assets, demonstrating discipline in cost management and capital allocation, and seeing strong momentum in new acquisition programs and podcasting growth. Management signaled continued focus on maximizing shareholder value through operational efficiencies, targeted investments, and enhanced capital returns as business improvements take hold.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Trinity Industries raises 2025 EPS guidance to $1.55-$1.70 as secondary market accelerates
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Trinity Industries, Inc. (TRN) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO E. Savage highlighted Trinity's decision to "raise and tighten full year EPS guidance to $1.55 to $1.70, reflecting our confidence in the business model and execution capabilities." Savage noted that "our leasing business continues to benefit from strong market dynamics, higher lease rates and favorable pricing on external repairs," and emphasized continued opportunities in the secondary market.
  • Savage reported that the Leasing and Services segment saw "revenue grew year-over-year, driven by higher fleet pricing and strong utilization of 96.8%," with renewal rates "25.1% above expiring rates in the quarter with an 82% renewal success rate."
  • Savage stated, "We added over $100 million of railcars into our fleet from the secondary market and sold $80 million of railcars in the quarter. We expect secondary market activity to accelerate in the fourth quarter."
  • On manufacturing, Savage said, "our team delivered impressive results, achieving a solid operating profit margin of 7.1% with a favorable mix of specialty railcars and improving operational efficiencies despite a lower delivery environment."
  • CFO Eric Marchetto remarked, "Total revenues in the third quarter were $454 million, down both sequentially and year-over-year due to lower external deliveries in the Rail Products Group. However, despite lower deliveries, earnings per share in the quarter of $0.38 are up sequentially due to the favorable margin performance in the Rail Products Group."
  • Marchetto added, "We are expecting full year SG&A savings of approximately 20% as compared to 2024 and we will end the year at a lower run rate as we move into 2026."

Outlook

  • Trinity raised and tightened full year EPS guidance from a range of $1.40-$1.60 to a range of $1.55-$1.70.
  • Marchetto stated, "We are maintaining our outlook of full year industry deliveries of 28,000 to 33,000 railcars, reflecting the muted current railcar environment."
  • Savage expressed confidence in the leasing market and noted, "We remain optimistic about the leasing market. Furthermore, the secondary market remains very active, and we have capitalized on good opportunities to optimize and monetize our fleet."
  • The company "expects substantial railcar sales in the fourth quarter, more than offsetting additions to the fleet from origination and secondary market purchases."

Financial Results

  • Marchetto reported "earnings per share in the quarter of $0.38" and "total revenues in the third quarter were $454 million."
  • Year-to-date cash flow from continuing operations was $187 million.
  • Year-to-date gains on lease portfolio sales were $35 million, with anticipated full year gains of $70 million to $80 million.
  • Trinity returned $134 million of capital to shareholders year-to-date through dividends and share buybacks.
  • The company reported a cash balance of $66 million and total liquidity of $571 million.
  • The Rail Products segment achieved a 7.1% operating margin with 1,680 railcars delivered in the quarter, and backlog stood at $1.8 billion, with approximately 21% expected to deliver by year-end.

Q&A

  • Andrzej Tomczyk, Goldman Sachs: Asked about the railcar delivery and order environment and book-to-bill expectations. Savage responded that "when you look at our projection for this year for industry deliveries, it's 28,000 to 33,000, which is below replacement level demand right now. And we're looking to see something similar in 2026 right now."
  • Tomczyk inquired about the FLRD drop. Savage explained, "When you look at the FLRD for Q3, it was the 17th consecutive quarter of positive FLRD. When you look at the step down, it was driven by higher expiring rates and some moderation in market rates for certain railcar types."
  • Tomczyk asked about repricing progress. Marchetto said, "it's about 65% of the fleet that's repriced. And we continue to see about 15% of that reprice in the year."
  • Bascome Majors, Susquehanna: Asked about renewal rates and FLRD. Marchetto clarified, "the 8% is the contracts that are expiring in the next 4 quarters -- same mix and everything else. So you do get a little bit -- you get -- the FLRD will get some volatility because we don't control for mix."
  • Majors also probed secondary market gains. Marchetto said, "we changed our guidance from $50 million to $60 million to $70 million to $80 million. And that is -- it is, as you mentioned, higher than we expected. We're seeing a really strong secondary market."
  • Majors asked about the ABS deal's credit investor appetite. Marchetto responded, "demand was really strong... It's flattering how the investors really want to invest in our paper."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed on delivery pace, order environment, and renewal rates, maintaining a neutral to slightly cautious tone with questions on FLRD volatility, secondary market sustainability, and manufacturing margins.
  • Management expressed confidence, especially in prepared remarks, citing "conviction in our margin performance" and an "outlook of full year industry deliveries of 28,000 to 33,000 railcars." During Q&A, responses remained steady though slightly more guarded when addressing uncertainties for 2026.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analysts' tone was more focused on explaining metrics volatility and sustainability of current gains, while management maintained a confident but pragmatic stance, especially regarding guidance and market challenges.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance was raised and tightened to $1.55-$1.70 EPS from the previous $1.40-$1.60 range, reflecting increased conviction in margin performance and secondary market gains.
  • The outlook for industry deliveries remained unchanged at 28,000 to 33,000 railcars, with continued mention of a challenging order environment.
  • FLRD (future lease rate differential) moderated from 18% in Q2 to 8-9% in Q3, while renewal rates increased from 17.9% above expiring in Q2 to 25.1% in Q3.
  • Secondary market activity intensified, with over $100 million of railcars added and $80 million sold in Q3, compared to $29 million in lease fleet portfolio sales in Q2.
  • Management's tone remained confident, highlighting cost controls and margin improvements, while analysts shifted to probing the sustainability of gains and explaining metric nuances rather than focusing on immediate recovery.

Risks and Concerns

  • Savage noted "persistent market uncertainty has delayed customers' decisions to invest in new railcars."
  • The company identified a "lower delivery environment" and "industry railcar orders remained depressed in the third quarter."
  • Marchetto mentioned "we are expecting full year SG&A savings of approximately 20% as compared to 2024" as a mitigation strategy, alongside "opportunistic" capital allocation and fleet management.
  • Analysts questioned the sustainability of secondary market conditions and the impact of delayed customer decisions, as well as the potential effects of industry consolidation and trade policy.

Final Takeaway

Trinity Industries raised its full year EPS guidance to $1.55-$1.70, supported by strong leasing performance, high renewal rates, and robust secondary market activity. Despite a lower delivery environment and ongoing market uncertainty, management expressed confidence in operational execution, margin improvement, and the value of its integrated platform. The company remains focused on cost control, capital returns, and opportunistic fleet management as it heads into year-end and prepares for 2026.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Wall Street observes mixed moves after key big tech earnings and U.S.-China trade talks
data.description:
Wall Street is mixed on Thursday as Meta (META) and Microsoft (MSFT) earnings failed to impress investors. Market focus now has shifted to Apple (AAPL) and Amazon (AMZN) ahead of their reports, while traders also digest the latest updates from U.S.-China trade talks.

Falling the hardest has been the tech focused Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) which was last lower by 0.7%. At the same time, the benchmark S&P 500 (SP500) was in the red by 0.3%, and the blue-chip Dow (DJI) was higher by 0.4%. 

From a sector point of view, six of the 11 S&P segments are trading up in the green with Financials leading the way. At the other end of the spectrum, the Consumer Discretionary space has suffered the most so far. 

U.S. Treasury yields climbed higher as the longer-end U.S. 10-year Treasury yield (US10Y) pushed up 2 basis points to 4.10% and the shorter-end U.S. 2-year Treasury yield (US2Y) moved up by 3 basis points to 3.63%.

Earnings data from Meta Platforms (META) and Microsoft (MSFT) have dampened market momentum with META down 11.5% and MSFT lower by 2.2%. At the same time, Alphabet (GOOG)(GOOGL) has responded positively to its latest earnings figures as it has climbed 5.4%.

In the day ahead, traders will get more tech earnings, with Apple (AAPL) and Amazon (AMZN) set to report after the closing bell.

"We expect Amazon to miss expectations in its Thursday earnings report, and this is why we believed they pre-announced so many layoffs this week. Amazon's stock has underperformed and it's not as good of a business as many on Wall Street think," David Trainer, CEO of New Constructs said.

"We expect Apple to beat Wall Street's earnings expectations on the back of strong iPhone 17 sales. These strong iPhone sales show that even in this AI world, we still need a strong network of physical devices to drive AI adoption and use, and Apple is at the center of that, even if their AI strategy is minimal," Trainer added.

U.S. President Donald Trump announced a one-year agreement with China covering rare earths and critical minerals, while also halving fentanyl-related tariffs on Beijing (from 20% to 10%), effective immediately, following his meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in South Korea on Thursday.

"Despite its brevity, it appears that there was some progress in U.S.-China trade negotiations. But perhaps not quite as much as President Trump had signaled earlier this week...There was no word on either the future of Taiwan or TikTok. So, summing up the conclusion to this historic meeting: underwhelming," David Morrison, senior market analyst at Trade Nation, said. 

Furthermore, the Fed on Wednesday reduced its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.75%-4.00%, its second straight cut, as it seeks to ease off the brakes in an effort to protect the labor market.

data.title: OneSpaWorld raises dividend by 25% to $0.05
data.description:
• OneSpaWorld (OSW) declares $0.05/share quarterly dividend, 25% increase from prior dividend of $0.04.
  • Forward yield 0.89%
  • Payable Dec. 3; for shareholders of record Nov. 19; ex-div Nov. 19.
  • See OSW Dividend Scorecard, Yield Chart, & Dividend Growth.
